These cannot be recontructed on the fly - making contacts and recruiting informants takes time, effort and above all - patience. Nine months isn't nearly enough time to create such a verification process. Here's the most damning part: Neither is nine months or even nine YEARS enough to rebuild a US Army division. content: I think that terrorism is something that is very difficult to prevent, no matter what measures are taken to combat it. Though it is subjective and often difficult to define, reasonable measures should always be taken to prevent terrorist attacks. More often than not it means that Federal and local law enforcement, combined with awareness, and national intelligence services need to work together to share information and investigate possible attacks. That alone would have probably prevented 9/11. We are a country of over 300 million people. One terrorist can kill hundreds or thousands depending on numerous and sundry factors.

content: Then let me put it this way, so you understand how much damage was done by the man: Think of it like pruning a tree. It's easy and fast to cut a branch off, but growing it back takes a good deal longer, sometimes years. So Clinton cutting the military and CIA HUMINT infrastructure was an easy, quick stroke of the pen. Simply sign the order and the funding stops. Soldiers and (more importantly) mid-grade officers and NCOs leave the service, not to return. Intelligence sorces, funded by CIA dollars and contacted by agents are simply not paid the next year, and no CIA operative is available to gather the intelligence, even if the money WAS available. And the country sleeps, unaware of the true impact of this 'pruning'. A crisis arises. Inexact intelligence sources show an increase in activity, but without the HUMINT sources we used to pay and support, we're stuck with only the shadow play of SIGINT, without on-the-ground verification means. These cannot be recontructed on the fly - making contacts and recruiting informants takes time, effort and above all - patience. Nine months isn't nearly enough time to create such a verification process. Here's the most damning part: Neither is nine months or even nine YEARS enough to rebuild a US Army division. None of those mid-grade officers and NCOs who left ever make senior rank. The slots they held in the 90s were not available for junior officers and NCOs to occupy when their time came. Those that did make mid-grade aren't enough to flesh out new units during a crisis - they're needed in the fighting line. Growth of the military cannot take place during wartime due to the immediate needs of the forces. The basic equipment issue would take a full year or two alone, but the biggest problem is personnel. You see, it takes a decade to create those mid-grade officers and NCOs that Clinton pruned in the 90s. You can grouse about needing a draft all you want, but someone has to train and lead those soldiers, and unless you want E-5s as company 1SGs or 1LT Battalion commanders, you're going to be hard pressed to adequately man the staff structure of these 'new units'. It just can't be done in the modern world without severe costs as these new Battalion and Brigade staffs learn the hard lessons in months when they should have years to perfect them. We've seen it before: Bull Run, Kassarine Pass, Task Force Smith. This was the cost of the 'peace dividend' that Clinton cashed during his time as President. The sad thing is, some of us who left anticipated in 1993-95 what might happen if we went to war again after Clinton's cuts, but the public was too enthralled with the booming economy and 'aw shucks' attitude of the POTUS to worry,...or care. quote: "God and the soldier we adore, in times of trouble, not before, With the crisis past, and all things righted God is forgotten, the soldier slighted." Winston Churchill Sullivan013
